raw_text:
GTA sequel is criminally good
 
 The Grand Theft Auto series of games have set themselves the very highest of standards in recent years, but the newest addition is more than able to live up to an increasingly grand tradition.
 
 The 18 certificate GTA: San Andreas for the PlayStation 2 could have got away with merely revisiting a best-selling formula with a more-of-the-same approach. Instead, it builds and expands almost immeasurably upon the last two games and stomps, carefree, over all the Driv3r and True Crime-shaped opposition. Even in the year that will see sequels to Halo and Half-Life, it is hard to envisage anything topping this barnstorming instant classic.
 
 The basic gameplay remains familiar. You control a character, on this occasion a youth named CJ, who sets out on a series of self-contained missions within a massive 3D environment. CJ can commandeer any vehicle he stumbles across from a push-bike to a city bus to a plane. All come in handy as he seeks to establish his presence in a tough urban environment and avenge the dreadful deeds waged upon his family. To make things worse, he is framed for murder the moment he arrives in town, and blackmailed by crooked cops played by Samuel L Jackson and Chris Penn. The setting for all this rampant criminality is the fictional US state of San Andreas, comprising three major cities: Los Santos, which is a thinly-disguised Los Angeles, San Fierro, aka San Francisco and Las Venturas, a carbon copy of Las Vegas. San Andreas sucks you in with its sprawling range, cast of characters and incredibly sharp writing.
 
 Its ability to capture the ambience of the real-world versions of these cities is something to behold, assisted no end by the monumental graphical advances since Vice City. The streets, and vast swathes of countryside, are by turns gloriously menacing, grungy and preppy. Flaunting awesome levels of graphical detail, the game's overall look, particularly during the many unusual weather conditions and dramatic sunsets, is stupendous. The outstanding bread-and-butter gameplay mechanics provide a solid grounding for the elaborate plot to hang on. Cars handle more convincingly than ever, a superb motion blur kicks in when you hit high speeds, and there's more traffic to navigate than before. Park your vehicle across the lanes of a freeway, and within seconds there will be a huge pile-up. Pedestrians are also out in force, and are a loquacious bunch. CJ can interact with them using a simple system on the control pad. They will pass comments on his appearance and credibility, aspects that the player now has control over. Clothes, tattoos and haircuts can all be purchased, and funding these habits can be achieved by criminal means or by indulging in mini-games like betting on horses and challenging bar patrons to games of pool. The character will put on or lose weight according to how long he spends on foot or in the gym. He will have to pause regularly in restaurants to keep energy levels up, but will swell up as a result of over-eating. And at last, this is a GTA hero who can swim.
 
 At a time when games are once again under fire for their supposed potential to corrupt the young, San Andreas' violence, or specifically the freedom it gives the player to commit violence, are sure to inflame the pro-censorship brigade. Developers Rockstar have not shied away from brutality, and in some respects ramp it up from past outings.
 
 When hijacking a car, for example, CJ will gratuitously shove the driver's head into the steering wheel rather than just fleeing with the vehicle. Indeed, the tone is darker than the jokey Vice City. The grim subject matter here hardly lends itself to gags in quite the same way as the cheesy 80s setting of the last game. This title, incidentally, is set in 1992, but that is really neither here nor there apart from the influence it has on the radio playlists. The wit is still present, just more restrained than in previous outings. A further reason for this is that the incredible range of in-vehicle radio stations available means you will spend less time happening upon the hilarious talk radio options, where GTA games' trademark humour is anchored. The quality of voice acting and motion capture is simply off-the-chart. The game's rather odious gangland lowlifes swagger and mouth off in a way that rings very true indeed. It is a testament to San Andreas' magnificence that it has a number of prominent flaws, but plus-points are so numerous that the niggles don't detract. The on-screen map, for instance, is needlessly fiddly, an unwelcome change from past editions. There is also a very jarring slowdown at action-packed moments. And the game suffers from the age-old problem that can be relied upon to blight all games of this genre, setting you back a vast distance when you fail right at the very end of a long mission. But the gameplay experience in its entirety is overwhelmingly positive. You simply will not be bothered by these minor failings. San Andreas is among the few unmissable games of 2004.
llama3.2:1b: GTA sequel is criminally good, builds and expands on previous games, setting high standards for the series.
Gameplay remains familiar but with added depth and realism, including more realistic graphics and detailed environments.
The game's ambition and attention to detail are impressive, capturing the spirit of real-world cities like Los Santos and San Fierro.
llama3.2:3b: The article discusses GTA: San Andreas, a game that exceeds expectations and lives up to the high standards set by previous installments.
It builds upon familiar gameplay mechanics and introduces new features such as a vast open environment, realistic city settings, and improved graphics.
The game's story is darker than its predecessors, with a more mature tone and realistic violence.
The article highlights the game's many strengths, including sharp writing, impressive voice acting, and addictive gameplay mechanics, while acknowledging some minor flaws.
gemma2:2b: GTA: San Andreas is an excellent sequel that pushes past the established formula to create an impressive and engaging gaming experience.
The game features a sprawling, detailed world, dynamic missions, and a captivating story featuring CJ, a young man seeking revenge in a challenging urban environment.
The game also offers a more realistic driving system, engaging interactions with pedestrians, and a wide variety of mini-games.
Despite controversial elements like the level of violence, GTA: San Andreas delivers a remarkable combination of style, substance, and technical prowess.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Grand Theft Auto series of games have set themselves the highest standards, but the newest game is more than capable of topping them.
The new game has a much deeper world with different characters and levels.
Its gameplay remains familiar but the graphics are really amazing, especially the soundtrack.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas sequel is highly acclaimed, building upon and surpassing past games with enhanced graphics, intricate storyline, and dynamic gameplay that includes vehicle handling improvements and lifelike character interactions in real-world settings such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Las Vegas.
Despite its violent themes, the game offers a compelling narrative focused on crime and freedom of action without compromising overall quality.
qwen2.5:3b: The Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas for PlayStation 2 is highly acclaimed, succeeding where predecessors might have faltered with a derivative approach.
It significantly expands upon previous entries, offering an immersive experience in a gritty urban environment.
While still retaining familiar gameplay elements like vehicle control and missions, the game showcases impressive graphical advancements, complex character interactions, and robust narrative depth.
However, it also includes notable flaws such as overly harsh character behavior, fiddly on-screen map, and jarring slowdowns during intense scenes.
Despite these issues, its overall impact is so strong that it remains a standout title in 2004, easily surpassing more conventional games of the year.
opencoder:1.5b: GTA sequel is not only about a well-deserved sequel, but it's also a movie and a fantasy that revolves around the role of a recently widowed youth named "CJ" who has set out to fulfill his dream of a high crime state in an alluring urban setting.
It's a tale of self-discovery and redemption, filled with intense storytelling and innovative gameplay mechanics that make the experience truly breathtaking.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: GTA: San Andreas is an enhancement of previous GTA series games with improved graphical detail over Vice City.
The game features enhanced gameplay mechanics like advanced vehicle control and high-speed handling.
It's set in a unique city landscape with vibrant colors and dynamic weather conditions, including dramatic sunsets.
CJ, the main character, can buy personal accessories and have appearance changes based on comments.
The game is praised for its depth and story but has minor issues that add frustration without overshadowing the overall positive experience.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Grand Theft Auto sequel, "San Andreas", has been praised for its tough-but-impressive gameplay, which is set in a massive 3D environment and includes realistic graphics, outstanding character design, and detailed storyline with multiple endings.

It's a fantastic mixture of open world and driving experience that allows players to customize their protagonist's appearance and actions throughout the game, with extensive action scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

The game's violence is ramped up and includes more gruesome weather conditions and dramatic sunsets, but the overall look and feel of the game is astounding, capturing the ambiance of San Andreas' sprawling cities as well as exotic locations like Peru and India.

A fantastic selection of in-vehicle radio stations and an incredible range of voice acting, motion capture, and high-quality video game graphics are all reasons why this game is considered one of the best of its genre.
Despite some slowdowns at action-packed moments and a needless on-screen map that's unneeded, San Andreas has all the ingredients to be considered a classic.
The title is set in 1992, which has influenced the game's tone and setting, but it doesn't detract from its remarkable achievements.
tinydolphin:1.1b: This review compares GTA: San Andreas, the eighth and final entry in the Grand Theft Auto series, to previous installments, highlighting its increased graphical quality and gameplay mechanics.
It praises the development team's ability to recreate diverse settings and environments, as well as its impressive character development and acting.
Although it mentions some minor flaws, the reviewer still finds San Andreas a must-play experience and highly recommended for fans of the franchise.
phi:2.7b: The Grand Theft Auto series has set the bar high with the latest installment, GTA: San Andreas.
It's a sprawling open-world game that allows players to control a character, CJ, and take on missions in a fictional state of San Andreas.
The gameplay remains familiar, but with improved graphics and motion blur effects.
The game features realistic driving mechanics and an extensive range of interactive characters, including pedestrians who will pass comments on CJ's appearance and credibility.
The game also includes a variety of mini-games, such as betting on horses and pool.
While the game is dark and violent, it has been praised for its excellent writing and voice acting.
San Andreas is a must-play for fans of the GTA series.
orca-mini:3b: It expands upon the last two games and builds upon an increasingly grand tradition.

The basic gameplay remains familiar, involving a youth named CJ who sets out on self-contained missions within a massive 3D environment and controls vehicles including a push-bike, a city bus, and a plane.
The game's overall look is stupendous, with realistic weather conditions and dramatic sunsets, and there is more traffic to navigate than before.
Cars handle more plausibly than ever, and there's more interaction with pedestrians, including buying and losing weight.
The character can interact with them using a simple system on the control pad.
Players can purchase clothes, tattoos, and haircuts to fund them.
The game has a dark tone, with violence and brutality ramped up from past outings.
The wit is still present but more restrained than in previous outings, and the quality of voice acting and motion capture is simply off-the-chart.
San Andreas' music and radio playlists are also impressive.
However, there are some flaws such as a clunky on-screen map and jarring slowdown at action-packed moments.
The game's overall experience is overwhelmingly positive, but some minor failings do detract from the overall excellence.
hermes3:3b: GTA sequel GTA: San Andrés is incredibly good, surpassing standards and outperforming other games like Driv3r and True Crime.
It has expansive gameplay with a sprawling city environment and sharp writing; graphics are detailed and immersive.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The newest addition to the Grand Theft Auto series, GTA: San Andreas, lives up to the high standards set by its predecessors and surpasses competition in various aspects.
It builds upon the last two games instead of merely revisiting the formula with a more-of-the-same approach.
The game's setting is the fictional US state of San Andreas, consisting of three major cities: Los Santos (Los Angeles), San Fierro (San Francisco), and Las Venturas (Las Vegas).
The characters in the game interact realistically and have various habits that affect gameplay, such as weight gain or loss based on activities like swimming or indulging in mini-games.
GTA: San Andreas' violence may raise concerns among some, but its developers at Rockstar haven't shied away from including darker elements in the game.
The tone is darker than their previous game, Vice City, and the subject matter doesn't lend itself to jokes like before.
Voice acting and motion capture are of exceptional quality, adding depth to the characters' dialogue.
Despite some flaws, such as a needlessly fiddly on-screen map and occasional slowdown during action sequences, the overall gameplay experience is overwhelmingly positive.
GTA: San Andreas is among the few unmissable games of 2004.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas for PlayStation 2 surpasses its predecessors by expanding significantly on the series' formula, offering a vast open-world experience set in the fictional state of San Andreas, which mirrors Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Las Vegas.
Players control CJ, a young man seeking to establish himself in a tough urban environment while avenging his family and dealing with corrupt cops.
The game features improved graphics, realistic vehicle handling, and a dynamic world where CJ's appearance, weight, and interactions with NPCs evolve based on player choices.
While the game retains the series' signature humor, its darker tone and increased brutality may attract controversy.
Despite minor flaws like a cumbersome map and occasional slowdowns, San Andreas' depth, storytelling, and gameplay make it an instant classic and one of 2004's must-play titles.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas game, set in the US state of San Andreas with three major cities, offers a grand expansion from its predecessors and stands out as an instant classic.
The story follows a youth named CJ as he seeks to establish his presence in urban environments while avenging family murders and navigating a brutal gangland.
The game's graphics are impressive, capturing real-world versions of the city settings.
The gameplay mechanics, including car handling, pedestrian interaction, and weight management, provide a solid foundation for the engaging story.
While the violence may inflame critics, the overall gaming experience is overwhelmingly positive, with superb voice acting, motion capture, and humor.
San Andreas ranks as one of the few unmissable games in its genre.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The latest Grand Theft Auto (GTA) game, San Andreas, for PlayStation 2, surpasses expectations and establishes itself as an instant classic within the series.
Despite not being a radical departure from previous titles, it significantly expands upon their foundation with enhanced gameplay mechanics, a more immersive 3D environment, and superior visuals.

Set in the fictional state of San Andreas, comprising Los Angeles-inspired Los Santos, San Francisco-like San Fierro, and Las Vegas-counterpart Las Venturas, the game captures real-world city ambiance with remarkable detail and detail.

Greater vehicular variety and control, including bikes, cars, and even aircraft;
2.

Improved driving physics, motion blur at high speeds, and more traffic;
3.

Interaction with an extensive cast of characters through a simple communication system on the controller;
4.

Customization options for character appearance, clothing, tattoos, haircuts, weight management, and even swimming;
5.

In-vehicle radio stations offering diverse music selections, some reflecting 1992's gangster rap influences;
6.

Superior voice acting and motion capture, bringing gritty, believable characters to life;
7.

A darker narrative tone with fewer jokes, focusing on the consequences of criminal actions;
8.
Mini-games for earning in-game currency, such as horse racing and pool challenges.

Despite minor issues like a fiddly on-screen map and jarring slowdown during intense moments, San Andreas offers an overwhelmingly positive gameplay experience with its intricate plot, engaging mechanics, and stunning visuals.
This GTA title stands out as one of the most notable releases of 2004, standing up against high-profile contenders like Halo and Half-Life.
